title: 16-B
statement: B. Burglar and Matchestime limit per test0.5 secondmemory limit per test64 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutA burglar got into a matches warehouse and wants to steal as many matches as possible. In the warehouse there aremcontainers, in thei-th container there areaimatchboxes, and each matchbox containsbimatches. All the matchboxes are of the same size. The burglar's rucksack can holdnmatchboxes exactly. Your task is to find out the maximum amount of matches that a burglar can carry away. He has no time to rearrange matches in the matchboxes, that's why he just chooses not more thannmatchboxes so that the total amount of matches in them is maximal.InputThe first line of the input contains integern(1 ≤n≤ 2·108) and integerm(1 ≤m≤ 20). Thei+ 1-th line contains a pair of numbersaiandbi(1 ≤ai≤ 108, 1 ≤bi≤ 10). All the input numbers are integer.OutputOutput the only number — answer to the problem.ExamplesInput7 35 102 53 6Output62Input3 31 32 23 1Output7

processed.result: You are given $n$ and $m$.  $n$ is the maximum number of matchboxes that can be carried. Each of the $m$ containers has $a_i$ matchboxes, and each matchbox contains $b_i$ matches.  Find the maximum number of matches that can be taken by choosing at most $n$ matchboxes from all the containers.

You have a bag with a limited capacity. There are multiple boxes, each containing a certain number of items.  Find the maximum number of items you can take from the boxes, without exceeding the bag's capacity.
